volumes.title: National Building Code of Canada 2020 - Volume 1

content.text: This Code applies to any one or more of the following:

clauses.text: the design and construction of a new [REF:term:bldng]building,
the [REF:term:ccpnc]occupancy of any [REF:term:bldng]building,
a change in [REF:term:ccpnc]occupancy of any [REF:term:bldng]building,

content.text: This Code does not apply to the following:

clauses.text: utility towers and poles, and television, radio and other communication aerials and towers, except for loads resulting from their being located on or attached to [REF:term:bldng]buildings,
mechanical or other equipment and [REF:term:pplnc]appliances not specifically regulated in these regulations,

content.text: This Code applies to both site-built and factory-constructed [REF:term:bldng]buildings. (See [REF:internal:nbc.divA.part1.sect5.appnote2].)
[REF:term:frm-bldn]Farm buildings shall conform to the requirements in the National Farm Building Code of Canada 1995.

Where a [REF:term:bldng]building is altered, rehabilitated, renovated or repaired, or there is a change in [REF:term:ccpnc]occupancy, the level of life safety and [REF:term:bldng]building performance shall not be decreased below a level that already exists. (See [REF:internal:nbc.divA.part1.sect5.appnote5].)

articles.title: Book I (General) and Book II (Plumbing Systems) of the Code

content.text: This is the first of the two Books, Book I (General) and Book II (Plumbing Systems), that together form the British Columbia Building Code.
Unless a Book is specified, references to "the British Columbia Building Code," "the Code," "this Code" and the like shall be read as references to the Book in which they appear.

articles.title: Appendices, Notes and References to Appendices and Notes have No Legal Effect

content.text: Except for Notes A-Table 9.23.3.5.-B and A-9.23.13., including Table A-9.23.13. in Division B, Notes to Parts of this Code have no legal effect.

revisions.summary: Amended title by striking out “Appendices,” and “and Annotations”

content.text: Compliance with this Code shall be achieved by

clauses.text:
complying with the applicable acceptable solutions in Division
B (see [REF:internal:nbc.divA.part1.sect5.appnote3]), or

except as required by [REF:internal:nbc.divA.part1.sect2.subsect1.art1.sent3], using alternative solutions, accepted by the [REF:term:thrt-hvng-jrsdctn]authority having jurisdiction under [REF:internal:nbc.divC.part2.sect3] of Division C, that will achieve at least the minimum level of performance required by Division B in the areas defined by the objectives and functional statements attributed to the applicable acceptable solutions (see [REF:internal:nbc.divA.part1.sect5.appnote4]).

content.text:
For the purposes of compliance with this Code as required in [REF:internal:nbc.divA.part1.sect2.subsect1.art1.sent1.clause2], the objectives and functional statements attributed
to the acceptable solutions in Division B shall be the objectives
and functional statements referred to in [REF:internal:nbc.divB.part1.sect1.subsect2].

An alternative solution shall not be used in place of an acceptable solution if the acceptable solution expressly requires conformance to a provincial enactment other than Book I (General) or Book II (Plumbing Systems) of the British Columbia Building Code.

Unless otherwise specified in this Code, the [REF:term:wnr]owner of a [REF:term:bldng]building shall be the person responsible for carrying out the provisions of this Code in relation to that [REF:term:bldng]building.
The [REF:term:wnr]owner of a [REF:term:bldng]building is in no way relieved of full responsibility for complying with this Code by the [REF:term:thrt-hvng-jrsdctn]authority having jurisdiction

clauses.text: granting a building permit,
approving drawings or specifications, or
carrying out inspections.

articles.title: Characteristics of Materials, Appliances, Systems and Equipment

content.text:
All materials, [REF:term:pplnc]appliances, systems
and equipment installed to meet the requirements of this Code shall
possess the necessary characteristics to perform their intended functions
when installed in a [REF:term:bldng]building.

All [REF:term:bldng]building materials, [REF:term:pplnc]appliances and equipment on the [REF:term:bldng]building site shall be stored in such a way as to prevent
the deterioration or impairment of their essential properties.

Unless otherwise specified, used materials, [REF:term:pplnc]appliances and equipment are permitted to be reused when they
meet the requirements of this Code for new materials and are satisfactory
for the intended use.
Personnel performing the installation, alteration, renewal or repair of a [REF:term:plmbng-sstm]plumbing system shall

clauses.text: possess a Canadian tradesperson's qualification certification as a plumber,
be an indentured apprentice supervised by a journeyperson who meets the criteria set out in [REF:internal:nbc.divA.part1.sect2.subsect3.art1.sent1.clause1], or
be the registered owner and occupant or intended occupant of the single detached dwelling in which plumbing work will occur.

sections.title: Divisions A, B and C of this Code

content.text:
Division A contains the compliance and application provisions,
objectives and functional statements of this Code.
Division B contains the acceptable solutions of this Code.
Division C contains the administrative provisions of this Code.
Parts 1, 2 and 3 of Division A apply to all [REF:term:bldng]buildings covered in this Code. (See [REF:internal:nbc.divA.part1.sect1.subsect1.art1])
Parts 1, 7, 8 and 10 of Division B apply to all [REF:term:bldng]buildings covered in this Code. (See [REF:internal:nbc.divA.part1.sect1.subsect1.art1])
Parts 3, 4, 5, and 6 of Division B apply to all [REF:term:bldng]buildings described in [REF:internal:nbc.divA.part1.sect1.subsect1.art1] and

clauses.text: classified as [REF:term:pt-dtr-b]post-disaster buildings,

used for [REF:term:mjr-ccpn]major occupancies classified
as

exceeding 600 m2
                               (metric) in [REF:term:bldng-r]building area or exceeding 3 storeys
                               (metric) in [REF:term:bldng-hg]building
height used for [REF:term:mjr-ccpn]major occupancies classified as

subclauses.text:
Group D, [REF:term:bn-nd-pr]business and personal services
occupancies,

Replaced Article 1.3.3.3. - Modified Sentence 1 to add exception reference and reorganized clauses; added new Sentence 2 to exclude buildings designed per Subsection 3.2.10. from Part 9 application.

paragraphs.content:
This Code is most often applied to existing or relocated buildings
when an owner wishes to rehabilitate a building, change its use, or
build an addition, or when an enforcement authority decrees that a
building or class of buildings be altered for reasons of public safety.
It is not intended that the NBC be used to enforce the retrospective
application of new requirements to existing buildings or existing
portions of relocated buildings, unless specifically required by local
regulations or bylaws. For example, although the [REF:standard:nrcc-nfc] could be interpreted
to require the installation of fire alarm, standpipe and hose, and
automatic sprinkler systems in an existing building for which there
were no requirements at the time of construction, it is the intent
of the CCBFC that the NFC not be applied in this manner to these buildings
unless the authority having jurisdiction has determined that there
is an inherent threat to occupant safety and has issued an order to
eliminate the unsafe condition, or where substantial changes or additions
are being made to an existing building or the occupancy has been changed.
(See also [REF:external:nfc]Note A-1.1.1.1.(1) of Division A of
the NFC.)

Relocated buildings that have been in use in another location
for a number of years can be considered as existing buildings, in
part, and the same analytical process can be applied as for existing
buildings. It should be noted, however, that a change in occupancy
may affect some requirements (e.g. loads and fire separations) and
relocation to an area with different wind, snow or earthquake loads
will require the application of current code requirements. Depending
on the construction of the building and the changes in load, structural
modifications may be required. Similarly, parts of a relocated or
existing building that are reconstructed, such as foundations and
basements, or parts being modified are required to be built to current
codes.

The NBC applies the same requirements to site-built and factory-constructed
buildings. However, it can often be difficult to determine whether
a factory-constructed building complies with the Code once it has
been delivered to the construction site because many of the wall,
roof and floor assemblies are closed in and so their components cannot
be inspected. [REF:standard:csaa277] was developed
to address this problem with regard to residential, commercial and
industrial buildings. This standard describes a procedure whereby
an independent certification agency can review the quality control
procedures of a factory and make periodic unannounced inspections
of its products. The standard is not a building code, only a procedure
for certifying compliance of factory-constructed components with a
building code or other standard. If a factory-constructed building
bears the label of an accredited certification agency indicating that
compliance with the National Building Code has been certified using
the [REF:standard:csaa277] procedure,
the accepting authority will have some assurance that the concealed
components do not require re-inspection on site.

On the other hand, standards in the [REF:standard:csaz240mhseries] do resemble a building code.
Most of the individual standards in the series contain requirements
regarding many issues also covered in the NBC. Some of these [REF:standard:csaz240mhseries] provisions are performance
requirements with no quantitative criteria, some simply reference
the applicable NBC requirements, while others contain requirements
that differ from those in the NBC. Because it would be illogical to
have two different sets of requirements for buildings—one set that
applies to site-built buildings and one set that applies to factory-constructed
buildings—the NBC does not reference these [REF:standard:csaz240mhseries] standards. One of the individual
standards in the [REF:standard:csaz240mhseries] deals with special requirements for manufactured homes related
to the fact that these houses must be moved over roads, which is an
issue the NBC does not address. Therefore, labeling that indicates
that a factory-constructed house complies with the [REF:standard:csaz240mhseries] standards can NOT be taken
as an indication that the house necessarily complies with the building
code in effect for the location where the house will be sited.

If a building design (e.g. material, component,
assembly or system) can be shown to meet all provisions of the applicable
acceptable solutions in Division B (e.g. it complies with the applicable
provisions of a referenced standard), it is deemed to have satisfied
the objectives and functional statements linked to those provisions
and thus to have complied with that part of the Code. In fact, if
it can be determined that a design meets all the applicable acceptable
solutions in Division B, there is no need to consult the objectives
and functional statements in Division A to determine its compliance.

Where a design differs from the acceptable
solutions in Division B, then it should be treated as an “alternative
solution.” A proponent of an alternative solution must demonstrate
that the alternative solution addresses the same issues as the applicable
acceptable solutions in Division B and their attributed objectives
and functional statements. However, because the objectives and functional
statements are entirely qualitative, demonstrating compliance with
them in isolation is not possible. Therefore, [REF:internal:nbc.divA.part1.sect2.subsect1.art1.sent1.clause2] identifies the principle that Division B establishes the quantitative
performance targets that alternative solutions must meet. In many
cases, these targets are not defined very precisely by the acceptable
solutions—certainly far less precisely than would be the case with
a true performance code, which would have quantitative performance
targets and prescribed methods of performance measurement for all
aspects of building performance. Nevertheless, [REF:internal:nbc.divA.part1.sect2.subsect1.art1.sent1.clause2] makes it clear that an effort must be made to
demonstrate that an alternative solution will perform as well as a
design that would satisfy the applicable acceptable solutions in Division
B—not “well enough” but “as well as.”

In this sense, it is Division B that defines the boundaries
between acceptable risks and the “unacceptable” risks referred to
in the statements of the Code's objectives, i.e. the risk remaining
once the applicable acceptable solutions in Division B have been implemented
represents the residual level of risk deemed to be acceptable by the
broad base of Canadians who have taken part in the consensus process
used to develop the Code.

Where Division B offers a choice between several possible designs,
it is likely that these designs may not all provide exactly the same
level of performance. Among a number of possible designs satisfying
acceptable solutions in Division B, the design providing the lowest
level of performance should generally be considered to establish the
minimum acceptable level of performance to be used in evaluating alternative
solutions for compliance with the Code.

Sometimes a single design will be used as an alternative solution
to several sets of acceptable solutions in Division B. In this case,
the level of performance required of the alternative solution should
be at least equivalent to the overall level of performance established
by all the applicable sets of acceptable solutions taken as a whole.

A subset of the acceptable solutions in Division B may establish
criteria for particular types of designs (e.g. certain types of materials,
components, assemblies, or systems). Often such subsets of acceptable
solutions are all attributed to the same objective: OS1, Fire Safety,
for example. In some cases, the designs that are normally used to
satisfy this subset of acceptable solutions might also provide some
benefits that could be related to some other objective: OP1, Fire
Protection of the Building, for example. However, if none of the applicable
acceptable solutions are linked to Objective OP1, it is not necessary
that alternative solutions proposed to replace these acceptable solutions
provide a similar benefit related to Fire Protection of the Building.
In other words, the acceptable solutions in Division B establish acceptable
levels of performance for compliance with the Code only in those areas
defined by the objectives and functional statements attributed to
the acceptable solutions.

This concept relates to the provisions directly regulated by
this Code and does not apply to electrical service entrance requirements,
which are regulated by other documents.

content.text: The objectives of this Code are as follows (see [REF:internal:nbc.divA.part2.sect2.appnote2]):

objectives.title: Safety
objectives.definition:
An objective of this Code is to limit the probability
that, as a result of the design, construction or demolition of the [REF:term:bldng]building, a person in or adjacent to the [REF:term:bldng]building will be exposed to an unacceptable risk
of injury.

objectives.title: Health
objectives.definition:
An objective of this Code is to limit the probability
that, as a result of the design or construction of the [REF:term:bldng]building, a person will be exposed to an unacceptable
risk of illness.

paragraphs.content:
Objective OE, Environment (including its sub-objectives), is
attributed to the requirements in [REF:internal:nbc.divBV2.part9.sect36], which address energy efficiency for small residential
buildings and certain small non-residential and mixed-use buildings
(see [REF:internal:nbc.divBV2.part9.sect36.subsect1.art3]). The objectives, functional
statements and energy efficiency requirements for larger Part 9 residential
buildings as well as for non-residential buildings whose combined
total floor area exceeds 300 m2
                      (metric) and some
mixed-use buildings are addressed in the [REF:standard:nrcc-necb]

Any gaps in the numbering sequence of the objectives are due
to the fact that there is a master list of objectives covering the
four principal National Code Documents—the National Building Code,
the [REF:standard:nrcc-nfc], the [REF:standard:nrcc-npc] and the [REF:standard:nrcc-necb]—but not all objectives
are pertinent to all Codes.

Where the term “the building” is used in the wording of the
objectives, it refers to the building for which compliance with the
National Building Code is being assessed.

content.text: This Part applies to all [REF:term:bldng]buildings covered in this Code. (See [REF:internal:nbc.divA.part1.sect1.subsect1.art1].)

Except as provided
                                in [REF:internal:nbc.divB.part1.sect1.subsect3.art1.sent3]
                              [REF:internal:nbc.divB.part1.sect1.subsect3.art1.sent2] 
                                and as required by [REF:internal:nbc.divB.part9.sect7.subsect4.art3.sent2], the 
                            climatic and seismic values required for the design of 
                            [REF:term:bldng]buildings under this Code shall be in conformance with the
                            values established by the [REF:term:thrt-hvn]authority having jurisdiction.

Where they have not been established by the [REF:term:thrt-hvn]authority having jurisdiction, the climatic values required
for the design of [REF:term:bldng]buildings shall be in
conformance with [REF:internal:nbc.divB.part1.sect1.subsect3.art1.sent3] and the
values listed in [REF:internal:nbc.divB.appendixC]. (See [REF:internal:nbc.divB.part1.sect3.appnote2].)

The outside winter design temperatures determined from [REF:internal:nbc.divB.appendixC] shall be those listed for the January 2.5% values.
(See [REF:internal:nbc.divB.part1.sect3.appnote3].)

Where they have not been established by the [REF:term:thrt-hvn]authority having jurisdiction, the seismic values required
for the design of [REF:term:bldng]buildings under Part
4 and Part 9 shall be in conformance with [REF:internal:nbc.divB.appendixC]. (See [REF:internal:nbc.divB.part1.sect3.appnote4].)

Depth of frost penetration shall be established on the basis
of local experience.

Words and phrases used in Division B that are not included in
the list of definitions in [REF:internal:nbc.divA.part1.sect4.subsect1.art2] shall have the meanings that are commonly assigned to them in the
context in which they are used, taking into account the specialized
use of terms by the various trades and professions to which the terminology
applies.

Where objectives and functional statements are referred to in
Division B, they shall be the objectives and functional statements
described in Parts 2 and 3 of Division A.

Where acceptable solutions are referred to in Division B, they
shall be the provisions stated in Parts 3 to 10.

The words and terms in italics in Division B shall have the
meanings assigned to them in [REF:internal:nbc.divA.part1.sect4.subsect1.art2].

The symbols and other abbreviations in Division B shall have
the meanings assigned to them in [REF:internal:nbc.divA.part1.sect4.subsect2.art1] and [REF:internal:nbc.divB.part1.sect3.subsect2.art1]

Unless otherwise specified herein, the documents referenced
in this Code shall include all amendments, revisions, reaffirmations,
reapprovals, addenda and supplements effective to 15 July 2019.

Where documents are referenced in this Code, they shall be the
editions designated in [REF:internal:nbc.divB.part1.sect3.subsect1.art2.table1]

application_notes.title:
Objectives and Functional Statements
Attributed to Acceptable Solutions

paragraphs.content:
The objectives and
functional statements attributed to each Code provision are listed
in a table following the provisions in each Part.

Many provisions in Division B serve as modifiers of or pointers
to other provisions, or serve other clarification or explanatory purposes.
In most cases, no objectives and functional statements have been attributed
to such provisions, which therefore do not appear in the above-mentioned
tables.

Climatic
values for municipalities not listed in [REF:internal:nbc.divB.appendixC] can be obtained at [REF:external:https://www.climate.weather.gc.ca]www.climate.weather.gc.ca or by e-mail from the Engineering Climate Services Unit of Environment
and Climate Change Canada at scg-ecs@ec.gc.ca.

The 2.5% values referred to in [REF:internal:nbc.divB.part1.sect1.subsect3.art1.sent3] are
the least restrictive temperatures that can be used. A designer may
choose to use the 1% values given in [REF:internal:nbc.divB.appendixC],
which are in excess of the Code minimums but are considered acceptable.

[REF:internal:nbc.divB.part1.sect3.appnote4.figure1] illustrates how to determine the seismic hazard
values to be used in the application of the Part 4 and Part 9 seismic
provisions.

content.text:
This Part is concerned with the fire, structural, heating, ventilating
and air-conditioning performance of [REF:term:frm-bldn]farm buildings, as well as processes and operations carried out therein that involve
a risk of explosion, high flammability or related conditions that
create a hazard to life safety. (See [REF:internal:nbc.divB.part2.appnote2].)

Except as provided in [REF:internal:nbc.divB.part2.sect1.subsect2.art1.sent2], this Part applies to all [REF:term:frm-bldn]farm buildings as described in [REF:internal:nbc.divA.part1.sect3.subsect3.art5] and [REF:internal:nbc.divA.part1.sect3.subsect3.art6.sent1].

[REF:internal:nbc.divB.part2.sect2.subsect6]
                           [REF:internal:nbc.divB.part2.sect2.subsect7] do not apply to Group G, Division
4 [REF:term:mjr-ccpn]major occupancies.
Words that appear in italics are defined in [REF:internal:nbc.divA.part1.sect4.subsect1.art2].

Every [REF:term:frm-bldn]farm building or part of
a [REF:term:frm-bldn]farm building shall be classified
in accordance with [REF:internal:nbc.divB.part2.sect1.subsect4]

Portions of [REF:term:frm-bldn]farm buildings that
do not contain Group G, Division 1, 2, 3 or 4 [REF:term:mjr-ccpn]major occupancies shall be classified according to their [REF:term:mjr-ccpn]major occupancy as belonging to one of the
Groups or Divisions described in [REF:internal:nbc.divB.part3.sect1.subsect2.art1.table1] and those
portions shall conform to the requirements in Part 3. (See [REF:internal:nbc.divB.part2.appnote4].)

[REF:term:bldng]Buildings classified as a Group G,
Division 1 or 4 [REF:term:mjr-ccpn]major occupancy shall
not contain a Group A, B or C [REF:term:ccpnc]occupancy.

[REF:term:bldng]Buildings classified as a Group G,
Division 2 or 3 [REF:term:mjr-ccpn]major occupancy shall
not contain a Group A, Division 1 or 3, or Group B [REF:term:ccpnc]occupancy.

In a [REF:term:frm-bldn]farm building in which the
aggregate area of all [REF:term:mjr-ccpn]major occupancies in a particular Group or Division is not more than 10% of the [REF:term:flr-r]floor area of the [REF:term:tr]storey in which they are located, these [REF:term:mjr-ccpn]major occupancies need not be considered as [REF:term:mjr-ccpn]major occupancies for the purposes of [REF:internal:nbc.divB.part2.sect2.subsect2], provided they
are not classified as Group F, Division 1 or Group G, Division 1 [REF:term:ccpnc]occupancies.

subsections.title: Building Size and Construction Relative to Major Occupancy

articles.title: Farm Buildings with Multiple Agricultural Major Occupancies

content.text:
In a [REF:term:frm-bldn]farm building containing
more than one [REF:term:mjr-ccpn]agricultural major occupancy classified in more than one Division, the [REF:term:bldng-hg]building height and [REF:term:bldng-r]building area of the entire [REF:term:frm-bldn]farm building shall
be used in determining the construction requirements and the fire
safety requirements for each of the [REF:term:mjr-ccpn]major occupancies.

The space above a [REF:term:mzznn]mezzanine need
not be considered as a [REF:term:tr]storey, provided the
conditions of [REF:internal:nbc.divB.part3.sect2.subsect1.art1.sent3]
                           [REF:internal:nbc.divB.part3.sect2.subsect1.art1.sent4]
                           [REF:internal:nbc.divB.part3.sect2.subsect1.art1.sent5]
                           [REF:internal:nbc.divB.part3.sect2.subsect1.art1.sent7] are met.

Platforms conforming to [REF:internal:nbc.divB.part3.sect2.subsect1.art1.sent6] need not
be considered as a [REF:term:tr]storey.

articles.title: Group G, Division 1, up to 3 Storeys, Limited Area, Sprinklered

content.text:
A [REF:term:bldng]building classified as Group G,
Division 1 is permitted to be of [REF:term:cmbtbl-c]combustible
construction or [REF:term:ncmbtbl-]noncombustible construction, used singly or in combination, provided

clauses.text: the [REF:term:bldng]building is [REF:term:prnklrd]sprinklered throughout,
the [REF:term:bldng]building is not more than 3 [REF:term:tr]storeys in [REF:term:bldng-hg]building height,
the [REF:term:bldng]building has a [REF:term:bldng-r]building area not more than

subclauses.text:
2 400 m2
                                  (metric), if 2 storeys
                                  (metric) in [REF:term:bldng-hg]building height, or

articles.title: Determination of Requirement for a Fire Alarm System

content.text:
A fire alarm system complying with [REF:internal:nbc.divB.part2.sect2.subsect3.art1.sent2] shall be installed in a [REF:term:bldng]building that is not [REF:term:prnklrd]sprinklered throughout
and that

clauses.text:
contains a Group G, Division 1 [REF:term:mjr-ccpn]major
occupancy with an [REF:term:ccpnt-ld]occupant load more than 25, or

contains a Group G, Division 2 or 3 [REF:term:mjr-ccpn]major
occupancy

subclauses.text: in a [REF:term:bldng]building more than 1 [REF:term:tr]storey in [REF:term:bldng-hg]building height, or

content.text:
Except as otherwise provided in this Section, the fire alarm
system required by [REF:internal:nbc.divB.part2.sect2.subsect3.art1.sent1] shall
comply with [REF:internal:nbc.divB.part3.sect2.subsect4.art2]
                           [REF:internal:nbc.divB.part3.sect2.subsect4.art4]
                           [REF:internal:nbc.divB.part3.sect2.subsect4.art5]
                           [REF:internal:nbc.divB.part3.sect2.subsect4.art17]
                           [REF:internal:nbc.divB.part3.sect2.subsect4.art9.sent1]
                           [REF:internal:nbc.divB.part3.sect2.subsect4.art9.sent4].
The fire alarm system required by [REF:internal:nbc.divB.part2.sect2.subsect3.art1.sent1] shall be

clauses.text: a single-stage system in a Group G, Division 1 [REF:term:mjr-ccpn]major occupancy, and
a single- or 2-stage system in a Group G, Division 2 or 3 [REF:term:mjr-ccpn]major occupancy.

content.text: Where a fire alarm system is required by [REF:internal:nbc.divB.part2.sect2.subsect3.art1.sent1],

clauses.text:
the air-handling system, where provided, shall be designed to
prevent the circulation of smoke upon a signal from a duct-type [REF:term:mk-dtctr]smoke detector if the air-handling system
serves more than 1 [REF:term:tr]storey, and
a manual station shall be installed in every [REF:term:flr-r]floor area near every [REF:term:xt]exit.

content.text:
Except as otherwise provided in this Section, the structural
design of [REF:term:frm-bldn]farm buildings shall conform
to Part 4. (See [REF:internal:nbc.divB.part2.appnote14].)

Except as provided in [REF:internal:nbc.divB.part2.sect3.subsect1.art1.sent3], [REF:term:frm-bldn]farm buildings shall be classified
in the Low Importance Category as described in [REF:internal:nbc.divB.part4.sect1.subsect2.art1.table1]

Liquid manure storage tanks shall be classified in the Normal
Importance Category as described in [REF:internal:nbc.divB.part4.sect1.subsect2.art1.table1]

In lieu of the requirements of [REF:internal:nbc.divB.part4.sect2.subsect2.art1],
a [REF:term:brfc-nvt]subsurface investigation of the [REF:term:frm-bldn]farm building site is permitted to be carried
out by a suitably qualified person prior to or during construction.

subsections.title: Loads Due to Use and Occupancy

articles.title: Loads Supported on a Floor or Suspended from a Ceiling

content.text:
In addition to the requirements of [REF:internal:nbc.divB.part4.sect1.subsect5.art3], the specified [REF:term:lv-ld]live load supported on
a floor or suspended from a ceiling shall be not less than the applicable
value listed in [REF:internal:nbc.divB.part2.sect3.subsect2.art1.table1]

content.title: Minimum Specified Live Loads on a Floor or Ceiling

header_rows.content:
Minimum Specified [REF:term:lv-ld]Live
Load on Area of Floor or Ceiling, kPa

Minimum Specified [REF:term:lv-ld]Live
Load on Floor Slats, kN/m

content.text:
Areas designed for the accumulation of poultry manure, such
as solid floors and dropping pits under a wire floor, slotted floor
or cage, shall be designed for a specified [REF:term:lv-ld]live
load of not less than 1 kPa (metric) for each 100
mm (metric) depth of manure.

Where machinery or vehicles not exceeding 1 000 kg (metric) in gross weight are used for manure clean-out in a poultry barn,
the barn floor shall be designed for a specified two-wheel [REF:term:lv-ld]live load of not less than 6 kN (metric) in
addition to the specified [REF:term:lv-ld]live load prescribed
in [REF:internal:nbc.divB.part2.sect3.subsect2.art2.sent1].

Floors supporting stored products shall be designed for the
specified [REF:term:lv-ld]live load due to their intended
use and [REF:term:ccpnc]occupancy, but not for less than 5 kPa (metric). (See [REF:internal:nbc.divB.part2.appnote15].)

For unobstructed slippery roofs of [REF:term:frm-bldn]farm
buildings with a roof slope, α, greater than 15° (metric) but not greater than 60° (metric) from the horizontal, where
snow and ice can slide completely off the roof, the slope factor,
C_{s} shall be calculated as follows:[EQ:display:](See [REF:internal:nbc.divB.part2.appnote19].)

In a [REF:term:frm-bldn]farm building classified
as a Group G, Division 3 [REF:term:mjr-ccpn]major occupancy where heating and drainage systems are installed to prevent the
accumulation of snow and water, the supporting structure for the light-transmitting
roof areas is permitted to be designed for a specified roof snow load
of not less than 1 kPa (metric), provided

clauses.text:
the heating system is capable of maintaining a minimum interior
temperature of 10°C (metric) throughout the [REF:term:frm-bldn]farm building, and
an emergency power supply is provided that

subclauses.text:
is supplied from a power source such as batteries, a generator,
or a combination thereof, and

will continue to supply power to the heating system in the event
that the regular power supply to the [REF:term:frm-bldn]farm building is interrupted.

paragraphs.content:
Part 2
of the NBC contains specific requirements pertaining to farm buildings
because they have distinct characteristics compared to other types
of buildings: they have low occupant loads, are typically located
in rural settings, and house unique activities and contents. Part
2 does not apply to large farm buildings that do not qualify as having
“low human occupancy,” i.e., an occupant load of not more than 1 person (metric) per 40 m2
                      (metric) of
floor area.

The intent of Part 2 is to set forth measures to ensure the safety
of persons in farm buildings.

application_notes.title:
Major Occupancy Classifications
for Farm Buildings

paragraphs.content:
The following are
examples of the agricultural major occupancy classifications described
in [REF:internal:nbc.divB.part2.sect1.subsect4.art1.table1]:
                        
                           Group G, Division 1
                           
                              Farm buildings housing livestock with a below-floor storage
area for liquid manure
                              Feed mills
                              Grain elevators
                              Rooms for the bulk storage of dangerous goods classified
as flammable gases or compressed gases
                              Rooms for the bulk storage of flammable liquids
                              Rooms for the bulk storage of reactive materials
                           
                        
                        
                           Group G, Division 2
                           
                              Animal exercise facilities
                              Animal housing facilities, including, but not limited to,
facilities for livestock, facilities for alternative livestock and
game animals, facilities for fur-bearing animals, and facilities for
cultured fish and shellfish
                              Animal training facilities
                              Facilities for the packaging and processing of agricultural
products
                              Facilities for the production of plants and fungi, excluding
greenhouses
                              Farm workshops
                              Feed preparation centres
                              Feed storage facilities
                              Fruit and vegetable storage facilities
                              Grain, forage and feed structures
                              Milking facilities 
                              Storage facilities for farming equipment, implements and
machinery
                              Viniculture facilities
                           
                        
                        
                           Group G, Division 3
                           
                              Greenhouses
                           
                        
                        
                           Group G, Division 4
                           
                              Biomass facilities
                              By-product facilities
                              Digesters
                              Grain bins
                              Horizontal silos
                              Storage bins
                              Vertical silos

It is intended that portions of farm buildings that contain
permitted major occupancies other than agricultural major occupancies
be subject to the requirements of Part 3. Unless specifically referenced
in Part 2, the requirements of Part 3 are not intended to be applied
to portions of farm buildings meeting the criteria for the application
of Part 2 (see [REF:internal:nbc.divA.part1.sect3.subsect3.art5]
                     [REF:internal:nbc.divA.part1.sect3.subsect3.art6]).

The materials used in the construction of fire separations and closures
in farm buildings should be selected to minimize deterioration caused
by exposure to corrosive or humid environmental conditions.

content.text: This Part applies to all [REF:term:bldng]buildings covered in this Code. (See [REF:internal:nbc.divA.part1.sect1.subsect1.art1].)

Words and phrases used in Division C that are not included in
the list of definitions in [REF:internal:nbc.divA.part1.sect4.subsect1.art2] shall have the meanings that are commonly assigned to them in the
context in which they are used, taking into account the specialized
use of terms by the various trades and professions to which the terminology
applies.

Where objectives and functional statements are referred to in
Division C, they shall be the objectives and functional statements
described in Parts 2 and 3 of Division A.

Where acceptable solutions are referred to in Division C, they
shall be the provisions stated in Parts 2 to 9 of Division B.

Where alternative solutions are referred to in Division C, they
shall be the alternative solutions mentioned in [REF:internal:nbc.divA.part1.sect2.subsect1.art1.sent1.clause2].

The words and terms in italics in Division C shall have the
meanings assigned to them in [REF:internal:nbc.divA.part1.sect4.subsect1.art2].

The symbols and other abbreviations in Division C shall have
the meanings assigned to them in [REF:internal:nbc.divA.part1.sect4.subsect2.art1].
This Part applies to all [REF:term:bldng]buildings covered in this Code. (See [REF:internal:nbc.divA.part1.sect1.subsect1.art1].)

This Code shall be administered in conformance with the appropriate
provincial or territorial regulations, municipal bylaws or, in the
absence of such regulations or bylaws, in conformance with the Administrative
Requirements for Use with the National Building Code of Canada 1985.

For design carried out in accordance with Part 4 of Division
B, the [REF:term:dgnr]designer shall be a professional
engineer or architect skilled in the work concerned. (See [REF:internal:nbc.divC.part2.sect3.appnote1].)

Sufficient information shall be provided to show that the proposed
work will conform to this Code and whether or not it may affect adjacent
property.

Plans shall be drawn to scale and shall indicate the nature
and extent of the work or proposed [REF:term:ccpnc]occupancy in sufficient detail to establish  that, when completed, the work
and the proposed [REF:term:ccpnc]occupancy will conform
to this Code.

When proposed work is changed during construction, information
on the changes shall comply with the requirements of this Section
for proposed work.

Site plans shall be referenced to an up-to-date survey and,
when required to prove compliance with this Code, a copy of the survey
shall be provided.
Site plans shall show

clauses.text: by dimensions from property lines, the location of the proposed [REF:term:bldng]building,
the similarly dimensioned location of every adjacent existing [REF:term:bldng]building on the property,

existing and finished ground levels to an established datum
at or adjacent to the site, and

articles.title: Information Required for Fire Protection Components

content.text:
Information shall be submitted to show the major components
of fire protection including

clauses.text: the division of the [REF:term:bldng]building by [REF:term:frwll]firewalls,
the [REF:term:bldng-r]building area,

the degree of [REF:term:fr-prtn]fire separation of [REF:term:tr]storeys, shafts and special rooms or areas, including
the location and rating of [REF:term:clr]closures in [REF:term:fr-prtn]fire separations,

content.text:
Before a sprinkler system is installed or altered, plans showing
full details of the proposed sprinkler system and essential details
of the [REF:term:bldng]building in which it is to be installed
shall be drawn to an indicated scale.

Documentation conforming to this Subsection shall be provided
by the person requesting the use of an alternative solution to demonstrate
that the proposed alternative solution complies with this Code.
The documentation referred to in [REF:internal:nbc.divC.part2.sect3.subsect1.art1.sent1] shall include

clauses.text:
a Code analysis outlining the analytical methods and rationales
used to determine that a proposed alternative solution will achieve
at least the level of performance required by [REF:internal:nbc.divA.part1.sect2.subsect1.art1.sent1.clause2], and

information concerning any special maintenance or operational
requirements, including any [REF:term:bldng]building component
commissioning requirements, that are necessary for the alternative
solution to achieve compliance with the Code after the [REF:term:bldng]building is constructed.

content.text:
The Code analysis referred to in [REF:internal:nbc.divC.part2.sect3.subsect1.art1.sent2.clause1] shall identify the applicable objectives, functional
statements and acceptable solutions, and any assumptions, limiting
or restricting factors, testing procedures, engineering studies or [REF:term:bldng]building performance parameters that will support
a Code compliance assessment.

The Code analysis referred to in [REF:internal:nbc.divC.part2.sect3.subsect1.art1.sent2.clause1] shall include information about the qualifications,
experience and background of the person or persons taking responsibility
for the design.

paragraphs.content:
Part 4 of Division B is written on the assumption that structural
design will be carried out by a professional who is qualified to perform
such design. [REF:internal:nbc.divC.part2.sect2.subsect1.art2.sent1] is not intended to imply
that a professional may not also be required in the application of
requirements in other Parts of the NBC.

application_notes.title:
Information Required on Drawings
and Specifications

paragraphs.content:
Examples of information that should
be shown on architectural drawings and drawings for heating, ventilating
and air-conditioning systems are:
                        the name, type and location of the building,
                        the name of the owner,
                        the name of the architect,
                        the name of the engineer or designer,
                        the north point,
                        the dimensions and height of all rooms,
                        the intended use of all rooms,
                        the details or description of the wall, roof, ceiling and
floor construction, including insulation,
                        the details or description of the windows and outside doors,
including the size, weatherstripping, storm sashes, sills and storm
doors,
                        the size and continuity of all pipes, ducts, shafts, flues
and fire dampers,
                        the location, size, capacity and type of all principal units
of equipment,
                        the size, shape and height of all chimneys and gas vents,
                        the size and location of all combustion air and ventilation
openings, and
                        the location and fire-resistance rating of required fire
separations.

For the 1977 edition of the NBC, most imperial values in the
Code were converted to metric values. A document entitled “Metric
Values for Use with the National Building Code 1977,” published by
the NRC Associate Committee on the National Building Code, lists all
of the metric values and provides some commentary on the rationale
applied in the conversion process.

As explained in this document, the metric values of dimensions
were “rounded off to the greatest extent possible, consistent with
the sensitivity of the particular dimension to the standard of safety
to be achieved.” For more sensitive dimensions, such as heights of
handrails and guards, headroom clearances and design loads, the metric
values were rounded to a higher precision.

When reviewing workmanship, materials or construction for compliance
with the Code, for any measurement related to commonly available building
components and materials, the designer or another suitably qualified
person must consider the imperial value that formed the basis for
the original prescriptive requirement.

For instance, the metric values given for the spacing between
framing members are soft conversions, rather than exact conversions
of the original imperial values. However, it remains common construction
practice to arrange joists, rafters and studs in 12, 16 or 24
in. (metric) increments so as to properly align them with the edges
of sheathing materials. It is, therefore, assumed that framing members
will be spaced according to the exact metric equivalents as shown
for the examples in the following table.

Although the word “house” is used in the terms “proposed house,”
“reference house” and “house performance compliance calculation report”
in [REF:internal:nbc.divC.part2.sect2.subsect8], it is intended to include other
types of residential buildings also addressed by [REF:internal:nbc.divBV2.part9.sect36.subsect5]. The terms “proposed building,” “reference
building” and “building performance compliance calculation report”
used in the [REF:standard:nrcc-necb] apply to other types of buildings.

The performance compliance calculation method detailed in [REF:internal:nbc.divBV2.part9.sect36.subsect5] uses a number of assumptions
regarding environmental values and operating conditions in order to
standardize the calculations and neutralize the impact of occupant
behaviour or to exclude issues that are not addressed in the requirements.
Note that the result of the energy model calculations is not a prediction
of the actual energy consumption of the proposed house.

volumes.title: National Building Code of Canada 2020 - Volume 2

content.text:
The application of this Part shall be as described in [REF:internal:nbc.divA.part1.sect3.subsect3]. (See [REF:internal:nbc.divBV2.part9.appnote1] regarding application to seasonally and intermittently
occupied [REF:term:bldng]buildings.)

revisions.summary: Added Sentence 9.1.1.1.(3) to clarify Part 9 does not apply to buildings designed under Subsection 3.2.10

content.text: Words in italics are defined in [REF:internal:nbc.divA.part1.sect4.subsect1.art2].

Except as provided in [REF:internal:nbc.divBV2.part9.sect3.subsect1.art1.sent2] and [REF:internal:nbc.divBV2.part9.sect3.subsect1.art6]
                           [REF:internal:nbc.divBV2.part9.sect3.subsect1.art7], unreinforced and nominally
reinforced concrete shall be designed, mixed, placed, cured and tested
in accordance with the requirements for “R” class concrete stated
in [REF:external:csaa23.1]Section 9 of 
                           [REF:standard:csaa23.1]

Unreinforced and nominally reinforced site-batched concrete
shall be designed, mixed, placed and cured in accordance with [REF:internal:nbc.divBV2.part9.sect3.subsect1.art2]
                           [REF:internal:nbc.divBV2.part9.sect3.subsect1.art9]

Except as provided in [REF:internal:nbc.divBV2.part9.sect3.subsect1.art1.sent4], reinforced concrete shall be designed to conform to the requirements
of Part 4.

For flat insulating concrete form walls not exceeding 2 storeys
                            (metric) in [REF:term:bldng-hg]building height and having a maximum floor to floor height
of 3 m (metric), in [REF:term:bldng]buildings of light-frame
construction, the concrete and reinforcing shall comply with Part
4 or

clauses.text: the concrete shall conform to [REF:standard:csaa23.1] with a maximum aggregate size of 19 mm (metric), and
the reinforcing shall

Where 38 mm × 140 mm (metric) framing is used and absorptive material

Typical [REF:term:stc]Sound Transmission Class
                              [REF:table-note:nbc.divBV2.part9.spectables1.table1.note2]
                              Sound
ratings listed are based on the most reliable laboratory test data
available for specimens conforming to installation details required
by [REF:standard:csaa82.31] Results of specific
tests may differ slightly because of measurement precision and minor
variations in construction details. These results should only be used
where the actual construction details, including spacing of fasteners
and supporting framing, correspond exactly to the details of the test
specimens on which the ratings are based. For wood- and steel-framed assemblies, if the fasteners
are spaced less than 300 mm o.c. (metric), subtract 1 from the [REF:term:stc]sound transmission class value; if the fasteners
are spaced less than 200 mm o.c. (metric), subtract 2 from the [REF:term:stc]sound transmission class value. Narrower fastener
spacing is not detrimental to the [REF:term:fr-rtnc-]fire-resistance
rating. Assemblies with  [REF:term:stc]sound
transmission class ratings of 50 or more require methods to minimize airborne sound
transmission at electrical boxes and other openings,
and at the junction of intersecting walls and floors, except intersection
of walls constructed of concrete or [REF:term:sld-m-u]solid masonry
units where the masonry joints at the intersection are mortared.
                              Sound ratings are only valid
where there are no discernible cracks or voids in the visible surfaces.
For concrete blocks, surfaces must be sealed by at least 2 coats of
paint or other surface finish described in [REF:internal:nbc.divBV2.part9.sect29] to prevent sound leakage.

application_notes.title:
Application of Part 9 to Seasonally
and Intermittently Occupied Buildings

paragraphs.content:
The National Building
Code does not provide separate requirements which would apply to seasonally
or intermittently occupied buildings. Without compromising the basic
health and safety provisions, however, various requirements in Part
9 recognize that leniency may be appropriate in some circumstances.
With greater use of “cottages” through the winter months, the proliferation
of seasonally occupied multiple-dwelling buildings and the increasing
installation of modern conveniences in these buildings, the number
and extent of possible exceptions is reduced.

[REF:internal:nbc.divBV2.part9.sect37.subsect1.art3.sent5.clause2] exempts seasonally occupied residential buildings such as summer cottages from the requirements of [REF:internal:nbc.divBV2.part9.sect37]. Cottages intended for continuous or regular winter use such as ski cabins are required to conform to [REF:internal:nbc.divBV2.part9.sect37].

[REF:internal:nbc.divBV2.part9.sect25.subsect2.art1] specifies that insulation is to be installed in walls, ceilings and floors which separate heated space from unheated space. Cottages intended for use only in the summer and which, therefore, have no space heating appliances, would not be required to be insulated. Should a heating system be installed at some later date, insulation should also be installed at that time in accordance with [REF:internal:nbc.divBV2.part9.sect25.subsect1.art1] and the insulation tables in [REF:internal:nbc.divBV2.part9.sect37]. However, if the building were not intended for continuous or regular winter use, it may still be exempted from the remainder of the energy efficiency requirements in [REF:internal:nbc.divBV2.part9.sect37].

application_notes.title: Ratio of Water to Cementing Material

paragraphs.content:
While adding water to concrete on site may facilitate its distribution
through formwork, this practice can have several undesirable results,
such as reduced strength, greater porosity, and more propensity to
shrinkage cracking. The ratio of water to cementing material is determined
according to weight. For example, using [REF:internal:nbc.divBV2.part9.sect3.subsect1.art7.table1], the maximum water-cement ratio of 0.45 for a 20 mm (metric) coarse aggregate would require 18 kg (metric) (or 18 L) of water
(1 L of water weighs 1 kg).

Lumber is generally grouped for marketing into the species combinations
contained in [REF:internal:nbc.divBV2.part9.appnote3.table1]. The maximum allowable spans
for those combinations are listed in the span tables for joists, rafters
and beams. Some species of lumber are also marketed individually.
Since the allowable span for the northern species combination is based
on the weakest species in the combination, the use of the span for
this combination is permitted for any individual species not included
in the Spruce-Pine-Fir, Douglas Fir-Larch and Hemlock-Fir combinations.

Facsimiles of typical grade marks of lumber associations and
grading agencies accredited by the Canadian Lumber Standards (CLS)
Accreditation Board to grade mark lumber in Canada are shown in [REF:internal:nbc.divBV2.part9.appnote3.table2]. Accreditation by the CLS Accreditation Board applies
to the inspection, grading and grade marking of lumber, including
mill supervisory service, in accordance with [REF:standard:csao141]

To identify board grades, the paragraph number of the NLGA [REF:standard:nlga_sgrcl] under which the lumber
is graded must be shown in the grade mark. Paragraph 113 is equivalent
to the WWPA [REF:standard:wwpa_wlgr] and paragraph 114 is equivalent to the WCLIB [REF:standard:wclib17] When graded in accordance
with WWPA or WCLIB rules, the grade mark will not contain a paragraph
number.

[REF:standard:nlga_sgrcl] permits lumber to
be dressed to sizes below the standard sizes (38 × 89, 38 × 140, 38
× 184, etc.) provided the grade stamp shows the reduced size. This
Sentence permits the use of the span tables for such lumber, provided
the size indicated on the stamp is not less than 95% of the corresponding
standard size. Allowable spans in the tables must be reduced a full
5% even if the undersize is less than the 5% permitted.

bc-cc-t-ccbl.definition: means an area and its facilities, or both, as required by this Code, which is easy to approach, enter, exit, operate, participate in, pass to and from, and use safely and independently by [REF:term:prsn-wth-dsblts]persons with disabilities.

cc-t-xt.definition: means that part of a [REF:term:mn-f-gr]means of egress within a [REF:term:flr-r]floor area that provides access to an [REF:term:xt]exit serving the [REF:term:flr-r]floor area.

bc-dptbl-dwllng-nt.definition: means a [REF:term:dwllng-nt]dwelling unit designed and constructed with some accessible features and which accommodates the future modification to provide more accessible features.

dfrzng.definition:
means the adhesion of [REF:term:l]soil to a [REF:term:fndtn-nt]foundation unit resulting from the freezing of [REF:term:l]soil water.
(Also referred to as “frost grip.”)

grc-ccp.definition:
(Group G) means the [REF:term:ccpnc]occupancy of a [REF:term:bldng]building or part thereof that is located on land that is associated with
and devoted to the practice of farming, and is used for the purpose
of producing crops, raising farm animals, or preparing, marketing,
storing or processing agricultural products. (See [REF:internal:nbc.divA.part1.sect5.appnote7.div1].)

grc-ccp-nh.term: Agricultural occupancy with no human occupants (Group G, Division 4)
grc-ccp-nh.definition:
means an [REF:term:grc-ccp]agricultural occupancy that is not intended
to be occupied by persons under normal use and is generally used for
the storage of agricultural materials and by-products. (See [REF:internal:nbc.divA.part1.sect5.appnote7.div2].)

r-brrr.definition:
means the assembly
installed to provide a continuous barrier to the movement of air.

r-pprtd-.definition:
means a structure
consisting of a pliable membrane that achieves and maintains its shape
and support by internal air pressure.

lrm-gnl.definition:
means an audible signal
transmitted throughout a zone or zones or throughout a [REF:term:bldng]building to advise occupants that a fire emergency
exists.

lrt-gnl.definition:
means an audible signal
to advise designated persons of a fire emergency.
